intro: Agelanthus tanganyikae, commonly known as the Tanganyika agelanthus, is a rare and unique plant species native to the island of Unguja in Zanzibar. It belongs to the family Cactaceae, which is typically associated with arid environments, yet this species thrives in a humid coastal setting. The plant is characterized by its spiny, cylindrical stems and clusters of small, yellowish flowers that bloom during the dry season. It has adapted to the specific microclimate of its habitat, which includes sandy soils and coastal breezes. Due to its limited distribution and ecological specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts.
